[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: SubscribeTransactionOutputsWithProofRequest] [Stream metadata forgery] Can an attacker forge subscription_stream_metadata with incorrect known_version_at_stream_start to receive data from the wrong starting point? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: SubscribeTransactionsOrOutputsWithProofRequest] [Subscription hijacking] Can two peers use the same subscription_stream_id to cause data races or stream corruption? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: SubscribeTransactionsWithProofRequest] [Stream start inconsistency] Can known_version_at_stream_start != known_epoch_at_stream_start (mismatched version/epoch) cause incorrect subscription initialization? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: SubscriptionStreamMetadata] [Stream ID collision] Can multiple clients generate the same subscription_stream_id leading to data confusion or stream takeover attacks? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: SubscriptionStreamMetadata] [Metadata replay attack] Can an attacker replay old SubscriptionStreamMetadata to restart a subscription from an old checkpoint, causing data duplication? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: GetTransactionDataWithProofRequest] [Max response bytes bypass] Can max_response_bytes = u64::MAX cause the server to attempt allocating massive memory for the response? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: GetTransactionDataWithProofRequest] [Max response bytes = 0] Can max_response_bytes = 0 cause division by zero or infinite loop when chunking response data? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: GetTransactionDataWithProofRequest] [Transaction data type confusion] Can switching between TransactionData, TransactionOutputData, and TransactionOrOutputData cause type confusion in response validation? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: GetNewTransactionDataWithProofRequest] [Version/epoch desync] Can known_version and known_epoch be from different blockchain forks, causing the server to return data from the wrong chain? (Critical)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: SubscribeTransactionDataWithProofRequest] [Subscription stream index overflow] Can subscription_stream_index wrap around from u64::MAX to 0, causing data loss or duplication? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Enum: TransactionDataRequestType] [Type variant mismatch] Can the server return TransactionData when TransactionOutputData was requested due to insufficient type checking? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: TransactionData] [Event inclusion inconsistency] Can include_events=false be ignored by the server, causing larger-than-expected responses that exceed max_response_bytes? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Struct: TransactionOrOutputData] [Output vs transaction size exploitation] Can an attacker toggle include_events to manipulate whether transactions or outputs are returned, bypassing size restrictions? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Function: is_optimistic_fetch()] [Classification bypass] Can a non-optimistic request be misclassified as optimistic to bypass lag checks in can_service_optimistic_request()? (High)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Function: is_protocol_version_request()] [Version request spoofing] Can an attacker send non-protocol-version requests that are misclassified as protocol version requests to bypass rate limiting? (Low)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Function: is_storage_summary_request()] [Summary request amplification] Can repeated storage summary requests cause expensive computation without rate limiting? (Medium)

[File: state-sync/storage-service/types/src/requests.rs] [Function: is_subscription_request()] [Subscription flood] Can an attacker create thousands of subscription requests to exhaust server resources since subscriptions are long-lived? (High)
